guide.introduction: Using a light sensor, some wire, and LEDs you can easily create an automatic night light that will turn on when you turn off the lights.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Using a light sensor, some wire, and LEDs you can easily create an automatic night light that will turn on when you turn off the lights.

Relevant parts
  • Arduino Uno
  • Solderless breadboard
  • LED, 3mm, any color
  • 330 ohm resistor
  • Resistor 10KΩ
  • Wire
  • LDR Light Sensor
  • 9v battery snap
  • Battery, 9V
Tools
  • Pliers
  • Wire cutters
  • Wire stripper

lines.text: These are the parts and tools you will need.
lines.text_raw: These are the parts and tools you will need.

lines.text: Connect the ground pin on the Arduino Uno to the ground rail on the breadboard. This is usually the first step in any project I do just so I can draw ground from any part of the rail.
lines.text_raw: Connect the ground pin on the Arduino Uno to the ground rail on the breadboard. This is usually the first step in any project I do just so I can draw ground from any part of the rail.

lines.text: Plug in your LDR Light Sensor into pin F 51 and F 53. Then connect a 10k resistor to G 51 and and G 46. Then a short wire from the ground rail to H 46. Then take a wire from the 5v pin on the Arduino to G 53. Then take a wire from digital pin 7 on the Arduino to H 51.
lines.text_raw: Plug in your LDR Light Sensor into pin F 51 and F 53. Then connect a 10k resistor to G 51 and and G 46. Then a short wire from the ground rail to H 46. Then take a wire from the 5v pin on the Arduino to G 53. Then take a wire from digital pin 7 on the Arduino to H 51.

lines.text: Now take a wire from the ground rail to I  40. Put a 330 resistor into H 40 and H 34. Take a wire from digital pin 1 on the Arduino to H 33. Since LEDs have positive and negative you will need to plug the longer end of you LED into G 33 and the shorter into G 34.
lines.text_raw: Now take a wire from the ground rail to I  40. Put a 330 resistor into H 40 and H 34. Take a wire from digital pin 1 on the Arduino to H 33. Since LEDs have positive and negative you will need to plug the longer end of you LED into G 33 and the shorter into G 34.

lines.text: Repeat the process with another LED but this time use digital pin 2 instead of digital pin 1.
lines.text_raw: Repeat the process with another LED but this time use digital pin 2 instead of digital pin 1.

lines.text: And repeat it again but use digital pin 3.
lines.text_raw: And repeat it again but use digital pin 3.

lines.text: Now plug the red wire of the battery clip into the Vin of the Arduino and plug the black wire into the GND pin on the Arduino.
lines.text_raw: Now plug the red wire of the battery clip into the Vin of the Arduino and plug the black wire into the GND pin on the Arduino.

lines.text: The Arduino code for the night light can be found in the PDF file above. Copy and paste it into the Arduino IDE, then upload it.
lines.text_raw: The Arduino code for the night light can be found in the PDF file above. Copy and paste it into the Arduino IDE, then upload it.

lines.text: Now your lights should turn on when the light sensor senses no light.
lines.text_raw: Now your lights should turn on when the light sensor senses no light.

guide.summary: Make a night light that automatically goes on when you turn off the lights.
